messageBody:
On Tue, 30 Sep 2003, Ilja Preuss wrote:

> > When you are benchmarking one thing against another, you
> > don't give one preferential treatment. You run them under exactly
> > the same conditions.
...
> Seriously, it depends on why you are benchmarking. When you are
> interested in speed of long running, server side software, start-up and
> warm-up time are quite uninteresting...

The test in question measured none of these things. It measured one
compute-bound activity repeated millions of times. I believe that any
optimizations would have occurred in the first few iterations. The test
itself was written in such a way as to absolutely minimize the effect
under test, the length of variable names; and that was only a small part
of the larger consideration. Java programs are slowed down by
interpretation and layers of abstraction.

When you set out to test something, you must first decide what it is that
you are testing and why. In part, this means paying close attention to
the other parties and the technical issues involved. Then you need to
design a test that reflects those considerations.

In this particular case, when asked, I said that a decent test would take
quite some time to devise. When the test we are talking about was
introduced, I pointed out that it was badly designed, but took it
seriously: I ran it different ways and carefully logged the results.
They weren't what I expected, but I reported them anyway. To put them in
perspective, I translated the test into C++ and reported those results
as well. Once again, they weren't what I expected (C++ results were
strongly influenced by variable names; Java results weren't).

For tests to be of any value, everyone needs to subject themselves to the
discipline of testing. This includes paying attention to and accepting
the results. When they aren't what you expect, you don't throw out the
tests, you try to understand.
